Catus: sleeps 2 hours, awake for 1 hour. Likes warm sunny days. Likes small wind.
Dogus: sleeps 1 hour, awake for 2 hours. Likes warm sunny days. Likes medium wind.
Frogus: sleeps 1.5 hours, awake for 1.5 hours. Likes cold cloudy days. Does not like wind.
Bober: sleeps 1 hours, awake for 2 hours. Likes warm sunny days. Does not like wind.
Fractal: sleeps 1.5 hours, awake for 1.5 hours. Does not care about weather since it is just an idea.
Dragon: sleeps 1.5 hours, awake for 1.5 hours. Different types of dragons like different weather
Alien: sleeps 1.5 hours, awake for 1.5 hours. Likes cold cloudy days. Likes medium wind.

The Necronomicon is a grimoire that contains forbidden knowledge, occult rituals, and descriptions of cosmic entities like Cthulhu and the Great Old Ones. It is a dangerous book that drives readers to madness.
Piece of cloth found at the crime scene.
Mysterious book found at a ritual site.
Not a very smart fish caught at the pond.
Found by Catus at the pond. Allows the spawning of new Froguses.
It has been with me for as long as I can remember.

Rescued from the hands of the powerful necromancer Valherris, it allows one to raise dragons.
Beautiful and reliable basket for storing eggs (with a lid).
A huge ruler, taller than me.

What Is Mathematics? - book by Herbert Robbins and Richard Courant

In the kingdom, the legendary mage’s name is not spoken aloud in haste. He was inscribed in the Book of Royal Archmages not with gold ink, but with black — the mark of those who gave their lives, leaving behind no school, disciples, or heirs, to save the world itself.

In the mage towers, students begin their training with the same legend. They are told of the Protector without followers — a mage who founded no order, wrote no treatises, and sought no recognition, but in his hour of need stood between the living and death.

Before difficult spells, young mages place their hand momentarily on the cold stone of the wall and whisper his name — not as a prayer, but as a reminder: true magic serves not glory, but choice.

The legendary warrior’s sacrifice is spoken of simply in the kingdom, without lofty words.

His sword was returned to its source — the family crypt — and it wasn’t the priests or military leaders who insisted on this, but the common people.

Peasants, merchants, and artisans leave small tokens of gratitude at the crypt entrance: a broken horseshoe, a piece of leather, a bundle of grain. No one calls it a tradition — it’s simply done when they remember.
They say he fought not for victory, but so that others would have time to escape, and therefore his sword shouldn’t be visible — it should rest.

Sometimes, on rainy days, a lantern is lit near the crypt. Not in honor of the hero, but so that the path home will always be illuminated, even if you never return.

The memory of the legendary bard lives in the kingdom not in stone or in books, but in voices.
His song has long since lost its words — everyone sings it in their own way, humming only fragments of a melody that cannot be captured in its entirety. But that’s how it’s passed on: not precisely, but vividly.

Children hum it as they play on the thresholds of houses, unaware of its origin. Travelers quietly pick it up on the road when the evening grows too long. No one calls it the memory of a hero — it’s simply a song that comes to them.

And on clear nights, when the moon hangs low, some swear the wind suddenly begins to sound smoother and warmer. And if you listen closely, it seems as if someone is singing nearby — not for glory or reward, but so that the road doesn’t seem empty.

The memory of the legendary blacksmith doesn’t resound loudly in the kingdom — it weighs heavily.
His hammer was returned to the forge of his hometown and hung by the hearth where he once worked. It’s no longer used to forge weapons, but it’s never removed: the fire in that forge has never gone out for a single night since.

A monument was erected at the capital’s gates — a stone anvil, crude and simple. It bears no names or inscriptions: everyone knows to whom it’s dedicated. On the opening day, the dwarves of the Ash Caves stood in a circle and silently struck the ground with their hammers. No songs, no speeches — only a dull, heavy sound that shook the stones.

Since then, they say: if the city gates suddenly become quieter than usual, it means someone has stopped at the anvil and remembered the one who once stayed so others could leave.

Few know that the mage’s curse began in the Misty Gorge. One of the illusions, not completely dispelled, touched his face — and from then on, half of his features seemed to have a life of their own: reflected in glass incorrectly, whispering other people’s thoughts, remembering things that never happened.

Over time, madness slowly began to consume him from within. Spells became increasingly difficult, sleep brought only fog, and his own reflection inspired fear. He tried to fight, sought healing, but realized that some distortions could not be reversed.

One day, he left alone, leaving no farewells. He was last seen at the edge of the Misty Gorge, where illusions never completely dissipate.
They say that now, among the shadows, one can discern a figure with a half-familiar face — it does not attack or call, only stares, as if still trying to remember who it was.

The warrior’s curse was born not of magic, but of a choice denied.
At Stone Pass, he was prevented from confronting the giant — and this decision, made out of caution, left a rift deeper than any wound.

Honor, unrequited, began to rot. He left alone, without words or witnesses, to reclaim what he considered rightfully his.

But when he returned to the pass, he was already broken: doubt dulled his hand, fatigue weighed his steps, and rage proved weaker than stone.

He didn’t last five minutes.

Now the giant wears his cloak, draped over his shoulder like a warm cloth. He doesn’t know it’s a trophy, doesn’t understand its significance — and in this final humiliation, the warrior’s honor dissolved completely, becoming nothing more than the wind on the pass.

The bard’s curse began in the Forest of Singing Winds, where he once dared to respond to the songs of the dryads. They managed to break through further, but the forest did not completely release him — part of the melody wove itself into his voice, leaving an alien rhythm within him.

Over time, the songs ceased to be quiet. They came in his dreams, interrupted his thoughts, compelled him to sing even when he was silent. His music became strange: it contained a melancholy that made the listeners’ hearts clench, and a call that made them want to go — not knowing where.

He resisted to the last, but one day he realized he could no longer distinguish his own desires from those whispered by the forest. On a windless night, he left his house and walked into the thicket, following the voices that now sounded like a sentence.

Since then, a wordless song is sometimes heard in the Forest of Singing Winds — uneven, broken. And those who recognize the human voice in it try to leave quickly: they say the forest sings through the one who once tried to answer it.

The blacksmith’s curse began in the Ash Caves, when he found red crystals, warm as life, amid the slag and rusty machinery. He mistook them for a rare ore and began studying them, testing their sound and impact, without noticing how they began to respond to him.

At first, the crystals merely drove him mad — distorting time, making him hear meaningful words in the grinding of gears. Then they sprouted: scarlet veins appeared beneath his skin, his bones grew heavier, his movements slower but stronger.

When he realized he could no longer distinguish his own will from the call of the earth, it was too late. He removed his hammer, left it at the entrance, and went deeper into the caves, where fire and stone never sleep.
They say that now in the Ash Caves, a mechanism that no one has ever set in motion sometimes moves, and in its rhythm one can hear the heavy breathing of one who has chosen to merge with the earth forever.

Night wrapped the village in thick velvet, and only a few fading window lights dared to rival the stars. The sky hung low and silent, as if holding its breath.

And then one of the stars flared.

At first, it was no more than a spark lost among the silver scatter of lights. Then its radiance began to swell with unnatural force, as though a fiery rift had opened in the very heart of the heavens. In a single instant, the darkness recoiled: rooftops blazed with cold brilliance, the well’s wooden beam flashed like steel, and sharp black shadows slashed across the earth.

It was not merely light — it was the cry of a dying sun, forged into a blinding crown of fire. The sky blossomed in orange flame, and for a fleeting moment it seemed that eternity itself had looked down upon the quiet village.

It hovered in the air, touching neither earth nor wind — a cluster of pure magic, radiating a soft yet unbearably deep light. Its surface flowed like living quicksilver, shimmering in shades of azure, gold, and a faint violet flame. Within it, tiny sparks flared and faded, as though stars were being born and extinguished in a sky too small for infinity.\n\nA quiet hum emanated from it, like the echo of a distant choir chanting ancient words long forgotten. The air around it thickened and trembled, grass bent low, and shadows stretched toward it as if drawn to a source of life. To come near was to feel your skin prickle, as though the very fabric of the world brushed against you with unseen fingers.

It towered above the village like a steel giant strayed from another world. Its matte-silver hull, traced with seams, resembled the armor of an ancient titan, while the rounded cockpit with its dark glass dome gleamed like an enchanted eye. Within its belly, an unseen force hummed softly — like a captive star bound obediently within iron ribs.

Massive supports, like the legs of a colossal guardian, pierced the earth, leaving faintly smoking marks in the grass from its recent landing. Along its sides protruded cylinders and structures — perhaps vessels of arcane ether, perhaps the organs of some mechanical beast unknown to humankind. Amber lights flickered beneath its hull, like the breathing of a dragon fallen asleep among fields and windmills.

Against the backdrop of blue mountains and a tranquil sky, it seemed a messenger from distant constellations — a wanderer descending into a realm of thatched roofs and pastoral calm. In its silhouette lingered ancient power and silent mystery, as though it carried legends of worlds where the heavens are roads and the stars serve as lanterns for travelers.

At the heart of the abyssal darkness, a star reached the limit of its nuclear endurance. Its core, compressed to an almost impossible density, collapsed in an instant and then unleashed energy rivaling the luminosity of an entire galaxy. The flash tore through the cosmic night — an overwhelming surge of gamma and X-ray radiation ripping through space as if the very fabric of reality had fractured.

The shockwave, expanding at thousands of kilometers per second, hurled layers of incandescent plasma into the vacuum. Swirling currents of ionized gas formed a radiant ring — the advancing front of matter enriched with heavy elements forged in the star’s final fractions of a second. Within this blazing cloud, gold, uranium, and other rare atoms were synthesized — the raw material for future planets and civilizations.
As the brilliance slowly began to fade, a сверхdense remnant remained behind — a neutron star or a nascent black hole. Space around it warped under extreme gravity, and for eons the surrounding galaxy would carry the echo of the catastrophe. It was not merely an explosion, it was a cosmic act of matter recycling, rewriting the chemical map of the Universe.

Transparent cylindrical capsule with metallic end caps. The glass body reveals its contents — inside, a bright orange-golden substance pulses, emitting a soft glow. The light reflects off the inner walls of the capsule, creating a sense of warmth and contained energy.

Inside the capsule is something resembling an alien organism. It looks like a living lava: a dome-shaped form rises at the center, with wave-like flows spreading outward, as if the liquid is in constant motion. Tiny sparkling points are visible throughout the mass, like microscopic flashes of energy.

The organism appears active and almost intelligent — its surface shimmers and seems to respond to its surroundings.

Necromancy is not merely the magic of death — it is a brazen defiance of time itself and the laws of the universe. A true master does not brandish a staff wildly but conducts a faint, whispered dialogue with the void, feeling for the thin threads of fading souls within the frozen haze of the Veil. To them, flesh is but clay and bone a mere framework, waiting to be imbued with a semblance of life by pouring ethereal energy — heavy as quicksilver — into cold, stagnant veins.

In the eyes of a necromant, the world is drained of color but teeming with shadows and echoes. Mastery is measured by sheer will: should one show a flicker of weakness or fear, the risen dead—driven only by hunger and residual malice — will turn their skeletal fingers upon their creator. The highest manifestation of power is not the raising of rotting hordes, but the ability to command an ancient wraith to divulge secrets of forgotten eras with a mere whisper, all while clinging to one’s own fading humanity.

The price of such dominion is always etched upon the mage’s visage: pallid skin, frost clinging to the fingertips, and a gaze fixed upon the infinite «nothing». Where an ordinary person sees only an end and decay, the master of necromancy sees an unfinished symbiosis, where death becomes just another stage of service. It is a path of solitude and eternal chill, where the only faithful companions are those who can no longer betray — for they are already dead.

Mastery of meditation is not merely a silencing of the mind, but the art of taming an internal storm. While the common man drowns in the chaos of his own thoughts, the true practitioner erects an impregnable citadel within the halls of the soul. With every deep breath, the boundaries of the self expand, blurring the line between flesh and ether, until the heartbeat synchronizes with the very rhythm of the earth.

At the peak of concentration, the world freezes like a fly trapped in honeyed amber. The master perceives mana flows invisible to the common eye, drifting through space, and senses the vibrations of others’ intentions long before they take shape. In this state of absolute stillness, the mind becomes like the mirrored surface of a mountain lake: it reflects the truth without distortion, remaining motionless even if a stone of rage or a blade of doubt is cast into its depths.

The highest tier of this art allows one to draw power from the Void itself. Shrouded in an aura of serenity, the meditator becomes an unshakeable pillar of existence, capable of mending wounds of spirit and body through sheer force of will. For such a master, time transforms into an obedient river and silence into a formidable weapon, for she who has fathomed her own depths gains dominion over reality without lifting a finger.

Home
Here you can see all your pets. Take good care of them!
Satiety
Each pet has 3 main stats: Satiety (green) - feed your pet when this stat is low.
Psyche
Psyche (blue) - it’s your animal’s mental health. Play with your pet to increase it and let your pet have a good UNINTERRUPTED nap. Your pet may not want to spend the time with you if you wake it up.
Health
Health (red) - it decreases if you pet’s satiety and psyche aren’t high enough. If it reaches zero, your pet will die.
Illness
Your pet might become ill. Ill pets are more needy. Their satiety and psyche decrease faster. You can heal an ill pet.
Clean up
Your pet will poop from time to time. Clean up after your pet to keep its psyche high.
Talk
You can talk to your pet in its own language, but it’s obviously not easy to talk to a pet. Play with your pets regularly to understand them better.
Age
Pets grow over time, from egg to adult. Their needs differ throughout their lifetime, so observe your pets carefully.
Good luck!
Take good care of your pets to keep them alive and happy! Good luck!

Do you know anything about the dug grave?
Nope, do not know anything
I do not know anything but we could investigate, bring me something from there.
Ok, I will see what I can find
Look what I have found near the grave
Hmm, interesting, let me see where it will lead me…
Have you found anything?
No, not yet, but I am searching.
Look, I have found this strange book on ritual site. Take it.
Thanks, do you know who can help me with it?
Try to ask catus they usually more experienced in wisdom stuff, the older the better.
One more thing, at the same ritual site I have found the body of the lost pet. Poor guy. Do not worry I will return him back to his grave.
[Show the book] Do you know anything about this book?
What is this? I can sense some magic but I am not sure…

Ahh, yes, I know what it is. This is Necronomicon. Very dangerous stuff, I recommend to destroy it right away, nothing good will come from it. However I can also teach you how to use it. Your choice. So do you want to use it or destroy it?
Hey buddy, I have noticed you barely touch your food, what is going on?
Yeah, you know what, I think I want some fish, could you catch me some? There is a lake nearby I think you can try there.
All right, let us see what I can do. I think I will come up with something on next day.
Oi mate, here is fish you have asked for. From very same lake you described.
Cheers mate, that is what I am talking about! Real fresh fish, el belissimo! Now I know this lake is good, think I will spend some time there by myself. Thanks again!
No problem!
Hey, what is that you are playing with?
Ah, found it on the lake. Round and rolling! Also smells like slime but it is okay. Here, take it, I am done playing with it.
Thank you, I think I know what to do with it.
Hey, do you know where all the eggs went?
Wow! I do not know anything about this, but I can look for it, ask me tomorrow, maybe I will find something.
I do not know anything and, honestly, I do not care.
Thank you, I will come see you tomorrow!
Well, did you find anything?
Nope, still looking.
Aha, I found all the eggs, well, you made me run! I suspect that they just rolled away or maybe the wind blew them away, I put them back in place, now they definitely will not roll away.
The eggs are missing again, do you know anything about it?
What, again? Oh my! Okay, I will look again, but after I find it, you better come up with something so that this does not happen again.
Ahahahahahahahaha! Seriously? Well, screw them.

Here they are, finally. Listen, I do not want to run around looking for the missing eggs again if something else happens to them. Ask someone else, maybe they can help, we need to solve this problem somehow.
Okay, I will ask around.
Maybe you know what to do with these constantly rolling eggs?
Hmm, I do not know how to help you with this, but I think I know someone who knows what to do. My friends from the pond, handy guys. I will ask them, come see me tomorrow.
I told you to ask someone else, do we all look the same to you?
Well, do I look like someone who can control the wind?
Well, have you heard from your friends?
They said they would do everything in the best possible way, wait a little longer.
Yes! Look what they just sent us - a beautiful, reliable basket for storing eggs (with a lid). And along with the basket they sent a Bober egg - lucky!
Truly a stroke of luck! I will have to try and hatch one or two.
I see you have been thinking about something a lot lately, is everything okay?
Yes, everything is fine, I am thinking about one interesting task and want to test it in practice, but I have paws. Will you help me?
Thank you! Then take this two-meter stick and go measure the length of the shoreline of our pond. I am very interested in how much you measure.
It will take me one day, I will report the results tomorrow.
Hi, I measured the length of the coast - it was 4.76 kilometers, what is next?
Very good, very good. Let us write it down - 4.76 kilometers. Now take this smaller ruler and do the same.
Okay, I will be back tomorrow with the results.
So, the survey is complete and some kind of devilry is going on there. This time the length of the coast was 5.12 kilometers. How so?
That, my dear, is the paradox of the coastline. If you want to know more about it, ask the bobers, they are good not only at carpentry, but also at mathematics.
That is what I will do.
Hi, frogus said you could explain the coastline paradox to me.
Aaaah, paradoks linii brzegowej? Wiemy, wiemy. Mam o tym bardzo ciekawą książkę. Przeczytaj ją, jest w niej mnóstwo ciekawych rzeczy.
Thank you very much, I think I will master it overnight.
Hey, my head is been buzzing with all sorts of thoughts lately. How do you always stay so rested?
Ah, well, we Doguses have been learning meditation since childhood. Do you want me to teach you?

To achieve enlightenment, do this:
1. Get a Frogus - they know everything there is to know about meditation.
2. As soon as it hatches, start practicing with it right away.
3. Practice meditating with it every day.
4. If you miss even one day, start over.
5. Finishing 10 exercises will allow you to achieve enlightenment.
It sounds confusing, but I will try.
Hi, dogus said you can teach me meditation.
Great, you have come to the right place. Let us start with something simple – breathing exercises. Repeat after me.
Sorry, but you are a bit late, you need to find a younger Frogus.
[Half an hour later] Well, that is great, come tomorrow, we will continue training.
Hi, I came to continue our training.
You came too early, not even a day has passed since our last training, rest for now.
Excellent! I see you are rested and ready to continue. Exercise for today is
Unfortunately, you are more than two days late. That is not how things work. We will have to start all over again.
Oh, oh, what can you do...
I have nothing more to teach you, child, you already know everything you need to know. From now on, you can free yourself from the thoughts that bother you at will. Congratulations!
Thank you for spending time with me! I have learned a lot.
Hi, I have heard some disturbing rumors about the kingdom, do you know what they are all about?

The king was looking for you... but I was tasked with speaking. Time is running out, listen carefully. Last night, the necromancer Valherris infiltrated the royal preserve and stole what should have been guarded for centuries — a dragon egg. The necromancer intends to perform a ritual that will transform the dragon hatchling into a soulless creature. If he succeeds, the world awaits times far more terrible than any war. We have five days, no more.
And what do you want from me?

You must assemble a party. Going there alone is certain death. But with the right pets… you have a chance.

Listen — you need four:
- Dogus the warrior, whose strength is like a hammer on an anvil, and whose courage is stronger than steel. He will lead you through any enemy ranks.
- Catus the mage — Well… that is me. And believe me, without my magic and knowledge of ancient runic paths, you will not get halfway.
- Frogus the bard — his voice can calm the storm and dispel illusions. You need him not only as a musician — he knows paths hidden from maps.
- Bober the blacksmith — he is a man of few words, but his hands can repair, destroy, or smelt almost anything. And without him, you will perish in the Ash Caves.
Four different pets, yep, I get it.
Return to me when you have gathered them all. Go. Time is our enemy. Find them. Gather a squad. And return the egg... before the world turns to ashes.
We will definitely cope!
I want you to join our team to save the dragon egg.
Are you absolutely sure about this?
Yes, I am sure you are the one we need!
Wait, I need to think some more.
Okay, I will go collect everything I need.
When you are ready, come to Catus mage, we will meet at his place.
Jestem zaszczycony takim zaufaniem! I will speak in a common language, it will be easier. Are you absolutely sure that I am the one you need?
Everyone is assembled, we are ready to move out.
Very well, our first goal is to reach the Misty Gorge. The journey there will take about a day, so do not waste your energy, let us get going!
Adventures await!
Haven’t we reached the Misty Gorge yet?
Not yet, be patient.
We’ve finally arrived, tell us what’s going on here.

We stand at the entrance to a gorge, shrouded in a thick silvery fog. Through it, distant whispers, footsteps, and strange laughter can be heard. The figures in the fog seem to be either human or monsters. I raise my staff, the crystal shimmers with an uncertain light.

Be careful. This is no ordinary fog. It’s saturated with the illusions of the ancient spirits of the gorge. It will distort distances, show false paths, make you see things that aren’t there... or things you’d rather not see at all. I sense that without the right approach, we could wander here for hours — or fall into traps.

Talk to everyone in the group. We all have our own ideas on how to best get through this place. You’ll have to choose the method that seems most suitable. When you’re ready, let me know your decision.
How do you propose to get through the Misty Gorge?
I can dispel some of the spell. Not completely, but enough to reveal the true contours of the path. This is the safest path.

To hell with illusions! It’s all smoke and terror. I’ll lead the way, cutting a path with my sword. If there are phantoms, I’ll chop off their heads. If there are traps, I’ll withstand the blow. We’ll get to the end if we simply move forward, not letting the fog take over our minds.

The gorge sings. Do you hear it? These voices respond to the melody. If I find the right rhythm, I can keep us sane and prevent illusions from penetrating our hearts. We will follow my song — it will become the thread that will lead us out of this nightmare.

Illusions? Hm. We’re not afraid of them if we leave our mark. Look: if I drive iron pegs into the ground every twenty steps, we won’t get lost. And illusions... illusions don’t care where the iron is. The work is time-consuming, but reliable.
I have heard all the options and am ready to decide what we will do.
Okay, so what did you decide?
I agree with Catus’s proposal.
I like Dogus’s idea
Frogus’s solution seems right.
I have confidence in Bober’s approach.
Actually, let me think a bit more...
Okay, we trust your judgment. We’ll prepare and act according to the chosen plan. If we try, we’ll be done in an hour. Forward!
How did we do?

We passed through the fog quickly and safely. At one point, I almost lost my concentration and one of the illusions almost distorted me, but I managed to pull through and led the group under a magical shield. We’re ready to continue our journey, our next destination is the Forest of Singing Winds, a journey that will take a day. Let’s go!

As expected, we quickly crossed the gorge. Dogus truly demonstrated his mastery of the sword, though it wasn’t particularly effective. One of the lurking illusions distorted half my face, but I noticed it in time and cast a spell to banish it. We’re ready to continue our journey, our next destination is the Forest of Singing Winds, a journey that will take a day. Let’s go!

I didn’t think Frogus’s plan would work, and I was surprised when the ghosts actually began to react to the rhythm of his melody. Not everyone reacted the same way, though — one of the lurking illusions distorted half my face, but I noticed it in time and cast a spell to banish it. We’re ready to continue our journey, our next destination is the Forest of Singing Winds, a journey that will take one day. Let’s go!

The Bober’s plan was indeed sound, albeit very slow. We fiddled around for so long that even the ghosts seemed to tire of it all and lost interest. I, too, soon lost interest, and in vain – one of the lurking illusions (which clearly hadn’t lost interest in us) distorted half my face, but I noticed it in time and banished it with a spell. We’re ready to continue on our way, our next destination is the Forest of Singing Winds, a day’s journey away. Onward!
Haven’t we reached the Forest of Singing Winds yet?
We’ve finally arrived, tell us what’s going on here.

We enter an ancient forest. The leaves tremble, though there’s barely a breath of wind. The air is filled with quiet yet eerie melodies — as if someone is singing from everywhere and nowhere at once. The voices grow louder, and the mood shifts strangely: now sudden joy, now melancholy, now a desire to stop and listen.

Wait... this is the Forest of Singing Winds. The ancient dryads cast a spell here to repel travelers. These voices affect the mind: they can lull you to sleep, lull you into oblivion, remind you of your most painful memories... We must pass quickly and resist their spell. Otherwise, they will lead us into the thicket, from which no one returns.

As before, talk to everyone in the group. We all have our own ideas on how to best get through this place. You’ll have to choose the method that seems most suitable. When you’re ready, let me know your decision.
How do you propose to get through the Forest of Singing Winds?
I have heard all the options and am ready to decide what we will do.

I can create a sound barrier, cutting off the dryads’ voices from our senses. A sphere of silence around us will allow us to pass more quickly. But it will require concentration... and if I weaken even for a moment, the spell might break through.

Spells, voices, songs… it’s all nonsense. If we just stick together and walk straight ahead, ignoring the voices, they won’t do anything to us. We plug our ears and move on. What could be so difficult?

Allow me. These melodies are no threat if you know how to respond. I can harmonize with the forest, align its voice with our steps. Then the dryads won’t touch us. I can’t promise the path will be easy... but we’ll remain sane.

Songs, whispers… they’re all empty sounds. If we create our own noise — loud, constant, rhythmic — the enemy’s melodies will lose their power. I can pound my hammer on my shield, setting the tempo. It will be unpleasant for everyone, but we will drown out their music.
How did we do this time?

We walked slowly, adjusting to the rhythm of the forest. Frogus certainly knew his stuff — his melody harmonized so well with the forest’s song that, by the end, we heard the dryads’ pleas — they begged us to leave Frogus with them — they liked him so much. It’s a good thing we’d already passed the forest by this time. We are ready to move on, to the Stone Pass, the journey there would take a day. Onward!

My sound barrier worked, and we truly walked in complete silence. However, towards the end, Frogus admitted that his perfect pitch had indeed picked up the dryads’ melodies — they were asking him to stay with them. Now he’s acting out of sorts and muttering occasionally. Don’t worry, he’ll be fine. We’re ready to move on to Stone Pass, it’ll only take a day. Let’s go!

Dogus’s plan was as simple as he was — and it worked! I didn’t expect it, I didn’t expect it. However, in the end, Frogus admitted that his perfect pitch had indeed caught the dryads’ melodies — they were asking him to stay with them. Now he’s acting out of sorts and muttering occasionally. Don’t worry, he’ll be fine. We’re ready to move on to the Stone Pass, it’ll only take a day. Forward!

It seems Beaver has no understanding of music at all. It was miserable for everyone — us, the forest, and the dryads. In the end, Frogus admitted that his perfect pitch had finally caught the dryads’ melodies — they were asking him to stay with them. Now he’s acting out of sorts and muttering occasionally. Don’t worry, he’ll be fine. We’re ready to move on to Stone Pass, it’ll only take a day. Let’s go!
Haven’t we reached the Stone Pass yet?
We’ve finally arrived, tell us what’s going on here.
At dawn, we ascend a high-mountain trail. The narrow road passes beneath overhanging cliffs. A huge figure appears on the path — a giant of gray stone, as if carved from the mountain itself.

He holds a massive stone club and blocks the way, looking at us with motionless but attentive slit-like eyes.\n\n“Stop. This is my pass,” he says. “No one passes until they prove themselves worthy. Either by strength, or honor, or wisdom. Decide.”

This giant is no simple creature. He is bound by an ancient pact with the mountains: to allow travelers through only after a trial. We must pass, otherwise we’ll have to find a way around… and that would be a waste of an entire day. We need to decide how to convince him. Return to me when you’re ready to make a decision.
How do you propose to get through the Stone Pass?
I have heard all the options and am ready to decide what we will do.
The giant’s skin is nearly impenetrable, but I have a spell that can blind him momentarily or create the illusion of a detour. We can get through while he’s disoriented. It’s dangerous… but possible.

It’s all perfectly clear. He wants a test, so I’ll give him one. I’ll challenge him to a fair fight, one-on-one. No magic, no tricks. If I can withstand his blow or force him to retreat, he’ll let us pass.

The giant is a great stone soul, let me turn to the ancient songs. I can soothe him, sing him a ballad of peace and freedom of the paths. Giants respect history and music — perhaps he will allow us to pass willingly, without a fight.

The giant is a stone. I am a blacksmith. We speak the same language. Allow me. I will offer to strengthen his club with my iron clamps. Improving the weapon is the best payment. Perhaps he will let us go for the work, without trials.
How did we manage to defeat the giant?

Dogus challenged the giant to a fair duel. Despite the difference in height, our brave warrior was head and shoulders above his opponent in terms of weapon mastery. The giant soon conceded defeat and said he would long remember such a skilled warrior. We passed without delay. Well, it’s time to move on to the Ash Caves. Forward!

We barely had time to slip past the giant while he was blinded by my spell. Dogus, a true fighter, was displeased that he wasn’t allowed to challenge the giant to a duel, but the main thing is we slipped past without losses. Well, it’s time to head for the Ash Caves. Forward!

I don’t know whether Frogus made up these legends himself or read them somewhere, but it seems the giant truly enjoyed his stories. At the end, he sat motionless, pensively, gazing into the distance — we realized this was our chance to get through, and we took it. Dogus, however, was dissatisfied with not being allowed to challenge the giant to a duel, but the main thing is we slipped through without losses. Well, time to head for the Ash Caves. Forward!

I had no idea that Bober had brought along a whole arsenal of tools for upgrading and modernizing weapons in the field. The giant was also taken aback by the offer and, after some consideration, agreed. Bober did a splendid job. Dogus was displeased that he wasn’t allowed to challenge the giant to a duel, especially since, he said, giant now had a more powerful weapon than before! However, the main thing is that we got through without losses. Well, time to move on to the Ash Caves. Forward!
Haven’t we reached the Ash Caves yet?

We descend into dark caves. The walls are covered in runes, and the ground vibrates beneath our feet. Deep below, the clatter of ancient machinery can be heard: the hiss of steam, the rumble of gears, the flashes of lava. Sharp gusts of hot air burst from the side pipes every now and then.
As soon as we take a few steps forward, one of the lattice doors slams behind us, forcing us to move only forward.

Be careful. These caves are the ancient workshops of the Ash Dwarves. Their technology combines mechanics and fiery runes. One mistake and we’ll end up under lava or trapped. But there’s no turning back. We must get through this scorching labyrinth. You know what to do.
How do you propose to get through the Ash Caves?
I have heard all the options and am ready to decide what we will do.

I have an idea. If we cool the air around us with ice magic, we can slow down some of the mechanisms. This will create a safe passageway. But fire and ice runes conflict… the consequences are unpredictable.

We’re wasting too much time. If we just move quickly, I can get through first and clear the way. Yes, it’s hot in some places, but we can’t stop. We’ll run where the furnaces are active and crawl where it’s too hot.

“The toothed wheels started spinning in my head.
In my wet head under the armor-piercing rain.”

Listen… these mechanisms work in rhythm. Can you hear it? “Knock-knock-shhhh” — repeating every few seconds. If we move to the rhythm, adjusting to the cycle, we can pass between the stoves and doors without coming into contact with the fire. The main thing is not to lose our rhythm.

This is my element. I know how these machines work. Give me time — I’ll check the pressure in the pipes, jam the dangerous gears, and shut down the unnecessary furnaces. If we follow me and do as I say, we’ll get through without any losses.
How did we manage to get through fire, water and copper pipes?

We moved very slowly and carefully, Bober checking any suspicious levers and mechanisms with particular care. A couple of times we stumbled upon some red crystals growing out of the walls, which greatly intrigued Bober, but I hurried him on, reminding him that he was responsible for our safety. Overall, we made it out without any casualties. We’re almost there — it’s a day’s journey from here to the ritual site. Onward!

My plan worked, though it required extreme concentration on my part. Now everyone’s sniffling. I didn’t have time to dwell on it, he seemed to have grabbed a couple of them, saying he’d study them in more detail later. We’re almost there — it’s a day’s journey from here to the ritual site. Let’s go!

We climb the shattered steps to the ritual chamber. The doors stand open, and an ominous green light pours from within. The air trembles with eerie whispers. In the center of the chamber stands a dragon’s egg, surrounded by runes. Valherris stands above it — tall, in tattered robes, his eyes as empty as night.

“It’s too late…” the necromancer says. “You’ve come too late. But if you want to die next to this damned egg, I don’t mind.”\nHe waves his hand, and hordes of minions burst from the shadows: skeleton knights, ghosts, shadows, and bone golems.

Valherris, you pathetic fool! Did you think I couldn’t recognize the spell of eternal summoning? You sold your soul in exchange for this final summoning, and your time is numbered! Now we can easily take the egg.

But there’s one problem… We’ll get the egg, but the minions will really be spawning forever. Whatever you say, that damn necromancer was incredibly powerful (now all that’s left of him is a robe on the floor). We don’t have much time, we can’t fight forever. One of us has to escape with the egg, and the others will buy him enough time. Decide, who among us will save the egg?
It seems I have no other choice…

But there’s one problem… We’ll get the egg, but the minions will really be spawning forever. I never thought I’d have to resort to the power of the Necronomicon. It’s powerful enough for one of us to hold off the creatures long enough for the others to escape with the egg. Decide which of us will buy the others time?
You will be the one who saves the egg…
I’m ready to make a choice…
Who did you choose?
I choose you, Catus…
I choose Dogus…
I choose Frogus…
I choose Bober…
Are you absolutely sure?
Yes, I am sure.
Let me think a bit more…
Well, in that case, it’s time to say goodbye. I’m putting Dogus in charge of the team. Talk to him, and I have to go. There’s something I need to sort out…
Goodbye, my friend
Catus put you in charge, tell me what happened

This is how it happened: Catus grabbed his staff, and a blue flame flared on it.

— Necromancy raised these creatures. Magic will stop them. Go away.

Drawing power from the cursed book, he creates a wall of energy that tears the air. The last thing you hear is his quiet voice:

The wall explodes with light, burying the mage and the hordes of the dead.
It’s time to go back, we don’t want his sacrifice to be in vain. The journey home will be easier and quicker, and it will only take one day. Let’s go!

Dogus places his cloak in your hands — he smiles for the first time in the entire adventure.

— Take the egg. I will hold them back. Go.

Touching the cursed book with his sword, he imbues it with mystical light. Turning, he charges into the ranks of the undead, shouting a battle cry that echoes throughout the hall…

Frogus clutches the lyre to his chest. His eyes are sad, but confident.

— We each have our own song, but the final one is always a solo. Remember me like this... singing.

Touching the cursed book, he raises the lyre and plays a note that cracks the air. The melody cuts through the undead like a blade, and then everything around it. The song fades along with the bard’s life, opening the way for you.

Bober places his hand on your shoulder and looks at you calmly, as if this were all just another day’s work in the forge.

— Iron bends under the hammer. And fate — under the choices we made. Go. I will bring down the halls behind me.

I saw it. And this, my friend, is not just a firework. This is Betelgeuse.
Betel… who?
Betelgeuse. A red supergiant. Once a star, it has decided to make a graceful exit — it has gone supernova. Such an event happens once every few thousand years.

Launch the probe. It should return within an hour.

A dog’s nose print is as unique as a human fingerprint. It can be used by forensic investigators to identify specific animals.
Dogs have three eyelids in each eye. The third lid, called the nictitating membrane, helps keep the eye lubricated and protected.
Bloodhounds have a sense of smell so accurate that it is admissible as evidence in a court of law. They can follow tracks that are over 300 hours old.

Your dog’s sense of smell is roughly 10,000 to 100,000 times more acute than yours. If you can smell a teaspoon of sugar in your coffee, they can smell a teaspoon of sugar in an Olympic-sized swimming pool.
Dogs have about 1,700 taste buds, while humans have around 9,000. This is why they are often more interested in how food smells than how it actually tastes.
A dog’s whiskers are packed with nerves that send sensory information to the brain. These «vibrissae» help them detect subtle changes in air currents and navigate in the dark.
Puppies are born deaf and blind. Their ear canals and eyes don’t fully open until they are about two weeks old.
Dogs can hear frequencies up to 45,000 Hz, whereas humans only hear up to 20,000 Hz. This allows them to hear the high-pitched «hum» of electronics that we can’t perceive.
Basenjis are the only breed of dog that cannot bark. Instead, they make a sound known as a «barroo», which sounds like a strange yodel.
Some dogs are «left-pawed» while others are «right-pawed». You can test this by seeing which paw they use first when trying to get a treat out of a toy.
Dogs sweat only through their paw pads. To cool down the rest of their body, they rely on panting to evaporate moisture from their tongues.
A dog’s ear is controlled by at least 18 different muscles. These muscles allow them to tilt and rotate their ears independently to pinpoint the source of a sound.
Newfoundland dogs have webbed feet and a water-resistant coat. This makes them world-class swimmers who were originally bred to help fishermen.
The Chow Chow and the Shar-Pei are the only two dog breeds that have completely black or blue tongues. Scientists aren’t entirely sure why this genetic trait exists.
Dogs can see in the dark thanks to a special membrane called the tapetum lucidum. This layer reflects light back through the retina, which also causes their eyes to glow in photos.
A dog’s shoulder blades are not attached to the rest of its skeleton. This «floating» design allows for greater flexibility and a longer stride when running.
The Lundehund is a breed with six toes on each foot. This physical anomaly helped them climb slippery cliffs in Norway to hunt puffins.
Small dogs generally live longer than large dogs. A giant breed like a Great Dane has a much faster metabolic rate, which contributes to quicker aging.
Dogs have a «nephrophilic» attraction to the smell of rotting things. They roll in stinky messes to mask their own scent, a behavior inherited from their wolf ancestors.
The average dog’s mouth exerts about 320 pounds of pressure per square inch. Some breeds, like the Mastiff, can exert over 500 pounds of pressure.
When a dog spins in circles before lying down, they are following an ancient instinct. Their ancestors did this to flatten tall grass and scuffle away any snakes or insects.
Dogs kick their back legs after pooping to spread their scent. They have scent glands in their paws that leave an «olfactory business card» for other dogs.
Many dogs experience «zoomies», technically known as Frenetic Random Activity Periods. This is a burst of pent-up energy that they release by sprinting in chaotic loops.
Dogs dream just like humans do. If you see their paws twitching or hear them whimpering in their sleep, they are likely in the REM stage of dreaming.
Your dog might lean on you as a way of showing affection or seeking security. In the dog world, physical contact is a sign of trust and bonding.
Dogs can learn to recognize over 150 words and gestures. Some «super-dogs» have even demonstrated the ability to understand up to 250 words.
When a dog wags its tail to the right, it usually means they are happy. A wag to the left can indicate that they are feeling anxious or threatened.
Dogs have a «sense of time» and can predict regular events like walks or dinner. They do this by smelling the «decay» of scents in the house throughout the day.
A dog’s «guilty look» is actually a reaction to your body language. They aren’t feeling moral shame, but are instead showing submissive signals to appease an angry owner.
Male dogs lift their legs to pee as high as possible. This makes their scent travel further and convinces other dogs that they are larger than they actually are.
Dogs often «smile» by pulling their lips back to show their front teeth. This is usually a submissive gesture intended to show they are not a threat.
The «wet dog smell» is caused by tiny microorganisms living in their fur. When the fur gets wet, these bacteria release volatile organic compounds that create the musk.
Dogs prefer to poop in alignment with Earth’s magnetic field. A study found they usually choose a North-South axis when the magnetic field is calm.
Staring into a dog’s eyes releases oxytocin in both the human and the dog. This is the same «love hormone» that helps mothers bond with their infants.
Dogs can smell your emotions, including fear and anxiety. When you’re stressed, you sweat a specific chemical that your dog can easily detect.
Puppies love to play-bite because it’s how they learn «bite inhibition». If they bite a littermate too hard, the other puppy yelps, teaching them to be gentle.
Dogs don’t actually feel «jealousy» in the complex human sense. However, they do show «primordial» jealousy when they see their owners giving attention to a rival dog.
Yawing is contagious between humans and dogs. Research suggests that dogs are more likely to catch a yawn from their owners than from a stranger.
Some dogs «point» by lifting one paw and aiming their nose toward prey. This is a natural instinct that has been exaggerated through selective breeding.
Dogs use their tails not just for emotion, but for balance. When running at high speeds, the tail acts as a rudder to help them make sharp turns.
The oldest known dog lived to be 31 years old. Bobi, a Rafeiro do Alentejo from Portugal, held the record until he passed away in 2023.
Greyhounds are the fastest dog breed on Earth. They can reach speeds of up to 45 miles per hour in just a few strides.
The Titanic had twelve dogs on board when it sank. Only three of them survived: two Pomeranians and one Pekingese.
Ancient Egyptians frequently mummified their dogs. They believed that these pets would act as guides and companions in the afterlife.
The Saluki is the oldest known dog breed. They appear in rock carvings dating back to 10,000 BCE and were favorites of Egyptian Pharaohs.
A Great Dane named Zeus holds the record for the tallest dog ever. He stood at 44 inches tall—nearly 4 feet—at the shoulder.
Conversely, the smallest dog ever was a Chihuahua named Milly. she stood only 3.8 inches tall, roughly the size of a pocket calculator.

In 1960, two Soviet dogs named Belka and Strelka became the first living creatures to orbit the Earth and return safely. Strelka later had puppies, one of which was given to President John F. Kennedy.
During World War I, the Sergeant Stubby became the most decorated war dog in history. He served in 17 battles and was promoted to Sergeant through combat.
The Beatles song «A Day in the Life» contains a frequency only dogs can hear. Paul McCartney added it at the end of the track specifically for his sheepdog, Martha.
Ancient Romans often put «Beware of Dog» signs (Cave Canem) in their entryways. These were usually mosaics of fierce-looking dogs on the floor.
Dalmatians are born completely white. Their iconic black or liver-colored spots don’t start appearing until they are about two weeks old.
The phrase «rain dogs and cats» may have originated in 17th-century England. During heavy storms, the bodies of stray animals would unfortunately wash down the city’s flooded streets.
Rin Tin Tin was a real German Shepherd rescued from a WWI battlefield. He went on to star in 27 Hollywood films and was a massive box-office draw.
The world’s most expensive dog was a Tibetan Mastiff sold in China for nearly $2 million. This breed is considered a major status symbol among the Chinese elite.
Poodles actually originated in Germany, not France. Their name comes from the German word «pudeln», which means to splash in water.
The «Poodle cut» was designed for function, not fashion. The puffs of hair were left to protect the dog’s joints and organs from cold water while they retrieved ducks.
An Alaskan Malamute named Balto became a hero in 1925. He led his sled team through a blizzard to deliver life-saving diphtheria serum to Nome, Alaska.
Dogs were the first animals ever domesticated by humans. Evidence suggests this partnership began between 15,000 and 30,000 years ago.
The «Dachshund» name literally translates to «badger dog» in German. Their long, low bodies were bred specifically to crawl into badger dens.
Chocolate contains a chemical called theobromine which is toxic to dogs. They cannot metabolize it as quickly as humans, leading to dangerous heart rates.
Grapes and raisins can cause sudden kidney failure in dogs. Even a small amount can be fatal depending on the dog’s size and sensitivity.
Dogs can suffer from seasonal allergies just like humans. Instead of sneezing, they usually react with itchy skin and excessive paw licking.
«Frito Feet» is a real phenomenon where a dog’s paws smell like corn chips. This is caused by a completely harmless buildup of Proteus or Pseudomonas bacteria.
An average dog’s body temperature is between 101 and 102.5 degrees Fahrenheit. This is significantly higher than a human’s average temperature.
Puppies have 28 «milk teeth» that they eventually lose. Adult dogs have 42 permanent teeth, which is ten more than adult humans.
Dogs can get sunburned, especially if they have white fur or thin coats. It is most common on their noses, ears, and bellies.
The «zoomies» are a sign of a happy, healthy dog. It shows they feel safe and have energy to burn in their environment.
Dogs are not actually colorblind, they just see a limited spectrum. They can see blues and yellows, but reds and greens appear as shades of gray or brown.
Many dogs are lactose intolerant. While they love the taste of milk and cheese, it often leads to digestive upset because they lack the enzyme to process it.
A dog’s heart beats much faster than a human’s. A resting dog’s heart rate is typically between 60 and 140 beats per minute.
Apple seeds and cherry pits contain tiny amounts of cyanide. While a couple won’t hurt, a large amount can be poisonous to a dog.
Dogs can get «kennel cough», which is essentially the canine version of the common cold. It is highly contagious but usually not life-threatening.
Some dogs are prone to «reverse sneezing». This sounds like a terrifying honking noise, but it’s usually just an irritation of the soft palate.
Just like humans, dogs can be left-handed or right-handed. Studies show that «ambilateral» dogs (no preference) may be more prone to stress.
Obese dogs are at a much higher risk for joint issues and diabetes. Keeping a dog lean can extend their lifespan by up to two years.
Dogs can have «phantom pregnancies». This is a hormonal imbalance that makes a female dog act like she is expecting puppies when she isn’t.
Petting a dog can lower your blood pressure. The physical act of stroking fur reduces cortisol levels in the human body.
Some breeds, like the Basset Hound, cannot swim well. Their heavy bones and short legs make it difficult for them to stay afloat.
Dogs have a specialized «vomeronasal organ» (Jacobson’s organ). This helps them pick up pheromones that aren’t detectable by the nose alone.
The United States has the highest dog population in the world. There are approximately 75 million pet dogs in the country.
A group of pugs is officially called a «grumble». This name likely comes from the snorting noises they make.
The Border Collie is widely considered the smartest dog breed. They are known for their incredible problem-solving skills and work ethic.
Dogs can be trained to detect cancer and low blood sugar. They do this by sniffing out «volatile organic compounds» in a person’s breath or sweat.
The «doggie paddle» is an instinctive swimming stroke. Even dogs that have never seen water will often start paddling their legs if held over a pool.
Service dogs are trained to know when they are «on duty». When their harness is removed, many of them immediately switch back into «playful pet» mode.
Some dogs have been known to «fake» an injury to get attention. If they notice you fuss over a limp, they may repeat the behavior for more treats.
The most popular dog name for decades was «Fido». In Latin, Fido means «I trust» or «faithful».
A dog’s whiskers are so sensitive they can detect changes in weather. They pick up on subtle drops in barometric pressure.
Every dog in the world is a descendant of a species of wolf that is now extinct. They are technically a subspecies known as Canis lupus familiaris.
There are over 400 million dogs in the world today. This includes pets, strays, and working animals.
Some dogs are trained to hunt truffles. While pigs were traditionally used, dogs are preferred because they don’t try to eat the expensive mushrooms.
The «Corgi» name is Welsh for «dwarf dog». Legend says they were used by fairies to pull their carriages.
An adult dog has the mental capacity of a 2-year-old human. This includes the ability to feel basic emotions and understand simple logic.
Dogs don’t like hugs the same way humans do. To a dog, putting your arms over their neck can feel like a dominant or threatening gesture.
The Siberian Husky was bred to run long distances with very little food. They have a unique metabolism that allows them to burn calories without using up their fat stores.
Three dogs survived the sinking of the Titanic. They were all small breeds that were likely carried into lifeboats by their owners.
A dog’s nose is wet because it helps them capture scent particles. They often lick their noses to «sample» the smells they’ve collected.
Labradors have been the most popular breed in the U.S. for over 30 years. However, the French Bulldog recently took the #1 spot in 2022.
Your dog truly loves you more than they love themselves. They are one of the only species on the planet that will prioritize your safety over their own.

Dogs often eat feces. This behavior, known as coprophagia, is often explained by survival instincts where dogs attempt to compensate for a deficiency in enzymes or nutrients. It can also be a behavioral habit inherited from their wolf ancestors, who did this to keep the «den» clean and protect the pack from parasites.
Cats have a specialized organ called the Jacobson’s organ located in the roof of their mouth. It allows them to «taste-smell» the air, which is why they sometimes stare at you with their mouths open.
A cat’s collarbone isn’t attached to other bones, it’s buried in their shoulder muscles. This allows them to squeeze their bodies through any space as narrow as their head.
Cats can rotate their ears 180 degrees independently of one another. They use 32 different muscles in each ear to pinpoint the exact source of a noise.
The «mew» is a sound cats developed almost exclusively to communicate with humans. Adult cats rarely meow at each other, preferring to use scent, body language, and tactile touch.
Cats have a third eyelid called a haw that is usually invisible. If you see it, it’s often a sign that the cat is feeling unwell or very sleepy.
A cat’s nose print is as unique as a human fingerprint. No two cats have the same pattern of ridges and bumps on their snouts.
Cats are «digitigrades», meaning they walk on their toes rather than the soles of their feet. This allows them to move faster and much more quietly than other mammals.
Their whiskers are roughly the width of their body. They use these highly sensitive hairs to determine if they can fit through a tight opening.
Cats have a right or left-paw preference, similar to human handedness. Research suggests that male cats are more likely to be left-pawed, while females lean toward the right.
The frequency of a cat’s purr—between 25 and 150 Hertz—can actually improve bone density and promote healing. They aren’t just happy, they are literally vibrating themselves back to health.
When a cat «kneads» you with its paws, it is a leftover behavior from kittenhood. They did this to their mothers to stimulate milk flow, and now they do it to you because they feel safe.
Cats sleep for an average of 12 to 16 hours a day. This means a seven-year-old cat has only been awake for about two years of its life.
If a cat brings you a dead mouse, they aren’t just giving a gift. They likely think you are a terrible hunter and are trying to teach you how to feed yourself.
A cat’s «slow blink» is a sign of extreme trust and affection. By closing their eyes, they are telling you they don’t perceive you as a threat.
Cats often get the «zoomies» after using the litter box. This is sometimes attributed to a «poo-phoria» caused by the stimulation of the vagus nerve.
Your cat likely recognizes your voice but chooses to ignore you. Studies show cats can distinguish their owner’s voice from strangers but don’t feel the need to respond.
Cats are crepuscular, not nocturnal, meaning they are most active at dawn and dusk. This is when their natural prey is usually most active and vulnerable.
When a cat rubs its face on you, it is «marking» you with scent glands in its cheeks. You have officially been claimed as their personal property.
Cats can jump up to six times their own height. Their powerful hind leg muscles act like springs to propel them upward.
A cat’s tail is a mood barometer, a slight twitch at the tip usually means irritation. However, a high, vibrating tail is the feline version of an enthusiastic «hello!»
In Ancient Egypt, if a family cat died, the owners would shave off their eyebrows as a sign of mourning. They would continue to mourn until their eyebrows grew back.
The first cat in space was a French feline named Felicette in 1963. She survived the trip and returned to Earth as a national hero.
Isaac Newton is often credited with inventing the cat door. He reportedly got tired of his cats scratching at the door while he was trying to study light.
A cat named Stubbs served as the honorary mayor of Talkeetna, Alaska, for 20 years. He spent his days drinking water spiked with catnip from a wine glass.
Black cats are considered bad luck in the US, but in the UK and Japan, they are seen as good luck. In some cultures, a black cat crossing your path is a blessing.
The CIA once spent millions trying to turn a cat into a spy by implanting a microphone in its ear. The mission failed when the «Acoustic Kitty» was hit by a taxi on its first outing.
There is a town in Taiwan called Houtong that is famous for its massive cat population. It was once a coal mining town but is now a major tourist destination for cat lovers.
Abraham Lincoln was a huge cat fan and used to feed his cats with gold forks at the White House. When asked if his husband had a hobby, Mary Todd Lincoln simply said, «Cats».
In the Middle Ages, cats were unfortunately associated with witchcraft and were often persecuted. This led to an explosion in the rat population, which worsened the Black Death.
Ancient Romans considered cats to be symbols of liberty and freedom. They were the only animals allowed inside their temples.
Cats cannot taste sweetness at all. They lack the specific taste receptors for sugar, so your cake is safe from them.
A cat’s brain is 90% biologically similar to a human’s. We share the same parts of the brain that control emotions.
Their night vision is roughly six times better than ours. They have a reflective layer behind their retina called the tapetum lucidum that makes their eyes glow.
Cats have a peripheral vision of 285 degrees. This wide-angle view helps them spot movement from almost any direction.
A cat’s heart beats much faster than a human’s, ranging from 110 to 140 beats per minute. That’s nearly double the average human resting heart rate.
Cats only sweat through their paws. If you see wet paw prints on a hot day, your cat is trying to cool down.
Female cats are typically right-pawed, while male cats are typically left-pawed. This sexual dimorphism in «handedness» is still being studied by biologists.
Cats have more than 200 million odor-sensitive cells in their noses. For comparison, humans only have about 5 million.
A cat’s tongue is covered in tiny hooks called papillae. These are made of keratin and help the cat rasp meat off bones and groom their fur.
They can drink seawater to survive if they have to. Their kidneys are efficient enough to filter out the salt and rehydrate their bodies.
Cats can make over 100 different sounds. Dogs, on the other hand, can only make about 10.
A group of cats is called a «clowder». A group of kittens is called a «kindle».
Cats are very sensitive to vibrations and can feel an earthquake coming 10 to 15 minutes before humans do. They often become agitated or try to hide right before a tremor.
Most cats are actually lactose intolerant. While they love the taste of milk, it usually causes them significant digestive upset.
House cats share 95.6% of their genetic makeup with tigers. Your fluffy friend is basically a tiny, living room-sized jungle cat.
Cats can move their top and bottom eyelids independently. This allows them to «squint» to protect their eyes while still keeping a lookout.
The richest cat in the world inherited $12.5 million from its owner. Blackie the cat lived a life of luxury while his owner’s relatives got nothing.
Cats have a unique walk where they move both right legs first, then both left legs. The only other animals that walk this way are giraffes and camels.
A cat’s whiskers are so sensitive they can detect changes in air current. This allows them to «see» where objects are in total darkness.
Cats spend about 30% to 50% of their waking hours grooming themselves. This helps them stay clean, cool, and free of scents that might alert predators.
Domestic cats can run at speeds of up to 30 mph. This makes them faster than Usain Bolt over a short distance.
Cats don’t have a «sweet tooth», but they are very attracted to the smell of animal fats. This is why they might try to lick your butter.
The oldest known pet cat was found in a 9,500-year-old grave on the island of Cyprus. This predates Egyptian cat worship by over 4,000 years.
A cat’s purr isn’t always a sign of happiness, they also purr when they are stressed or in pain. It is believed to be a self-soothing mechanism.
Cats have 230 bones, whereas humans only have 206. This extra count is mostly found in their highly flexible spine and tail.
The technical term for a cat’s hairball is a «trichobezoar». It sounds much more sophisticated than a wet lump of fur on the carpet.
Cats can spend up to 15% of their lives in «deep sleep». The rest of the time they are just «cat-napping», ready to spring into action at any moment.
A cat’s ear contains 32 muscles. These muscles allow the ear to act like a radar dish, scanning for the rustle of a mouse.
Cats have a special «vacuum» in their nose called the vomeronasal organ. It helps them analyze pheromones from other cats.
The world’s smallest cat, the Rusty-spotted cat, can fit in the palm of your hand. Despite its size, it is a fierce and capable hunter.
Cats are «obligate carnivores», meaning they must eat meat to survive. Their bodies cannot process nutrients from plants effectively.
A cat’s hunting style is «stalk and pounce». Unlike dogs, which chase prey over long distances, cats rely on stealth and a quick burst of energy.
Cats have a «righting reflex» that allows them to land on their feet most of the time. Their flexible spine and lack of a collarbone make this mid-air twist possible.
Some cats love water, specifically the Turkish Van breed. They are known as «swimming cats» because of their unusual love for taking a dip.
Cats have a very low thirst drive. In the wild, they get most of their hydration from the moisture in their prey.
A cat’s claws all curve downward. This makes them great at climbing up trees, but very bad at climbing down head-first.
Cats are effective at pest control because they kill for sport, not just for food. This «surplus killing» is a natural instinct to keep hunting skills sharp.
The «pouch» on a cat’s belly is called a primordial pouch. It protects their internal organs during fights and allows their bodies to stretch while running.
Cats can hear ultrasonic sounds. This allows them to hear the high-pitched squeaks of rodents that are silent to human ears.
Male cats that aren’t neutered have «chubby» cheeks called jowls. These are filled with testosterone-driven tissue to protect their faces during fights.
Cats can be «allergic» to humans. We produce dander and skin cells that can occasionally cause respiratory issues for sensitive felines.
A cat’s tail contains about 10% of its total bones. It acts as a counterweight to help them balance on narrow ledges.
Most cats don’t have eyelashes. Their prominent brow and blinking reflex provide enough protection for their eyes.
The «cat gap» refers to a period in North America where no cat fossils exist for 7 million years. Scientists are still unsure why they disappeared from the continent for so long.
Cats can dream just like humans. You can tell they are dreaming when their paws twitch or they make soft chirping noises in their sleep.
In some parts of the world, «Cat Cafes» allow people to pay an hourly fee to hang out with cats. This trend started in Taiwan and exploded in popularity in Japan.
A cat’s bite is highly prone to infection because of the bacteria in their mouths. Their sharp teeth act like needles, injecting bacteria deep into the skin.
Cats are very good at hiding pain. In the wild, showing weakness would make them a target for larger predators.
The phrase «the cat’s pajamas» was coined in the 1920s to describe something cool. It was part of a trend of nonsense phrases involving animals.
Some cats are «polydactyl», meaning they are born with extra toes. Ernest Hemingway famously loved these cats, and his estate in Key West is still full of them.
Cats have a «mirror neuron» system. This suggests they might be able to feel empathy or at least mimic the emotions of their owners.
If a cat’s whiskers are touched, it can trigger a «blink» reflex. This is a defensive measure to protect the eyes from potential debris.
Cats have a very short-term memory for things that don’t matter, but an incredible long-term memory for locations. They can find their way home from miles away.
The «scruff» of a cat’s neck has a special neurological trigger. When a mother cat picks up a kitten there, the kitten instinctively goes limp and calm.
Cats use their whiskers to judge if the air is moving. This helps them navigate rooms even if they can’t see anything at all.
A cat’s purr is often compared to a «lullaby» for themselves. They use it to lower their blood pressure and stay calm in stressful situations.
Cats can tell when you are about to go on a trip. They recognize the «suitcase ritual» and often sit inside the bag to prevent you from leaving.
When a cat is «chattering» at a bird through a window, it’s an instinctual jaw movement. They are practicing the «killing bite» they would use to snap the bird’s neck.
Cats have a sense of time. They know exactly when you are supposed to be home and will often wait by the door.
A cat’s field of vision is 200 degrees. This is 20 degrees wider than a human’s, giving them a slight advantage in detecting motion.
Cats can live to be over 30 years old. The oldest cat on record, Creme Puff, lived to be 38 years and 3 days old.
Calico and tortoiseshell cats are almost always female. The gene for the orange/black coat color is linked to the X chromosome.
A cat’s nose is as sensitive as a dog’s in many ways. They can smell things that have been in a room days after the object is gone.
Cats don’t see the world in black and white, but they don’t see colors as vibrantly as we do. They mostly see shades of blue and green.
If you keep your cat indoors, they can live up to three times longer than outdoor cats. This is due to a lack of predators, cars, and diseases.
Cats have a «homing» ability called magnetoreception. They use the Earth’s magnetic field to help them find their way back to their territory.
A cat’s skin is very loose. This is a defense mechanism that allows them to turn and bite a predator even if they are being held by the neck.
Cats can be trained to perform tricks, much like dogs. However, they require much more «bribe» (treats) and have a significantly shorter attention span.
The «cat’s meow» isn’t just a sound, it’s a manipulation. Studies suggest cats have evolved their meows to mimic the frequency of a human baby’s cry.
Cats believe they own the house, and you are just the staff. If you’ve ever owned a cat, you know this isn’t a «weird fact» — it’s the absolute truth.
The Wood Frog is a literal popsicle. It can freeze up to 65% of its body water during winter and thaw out perfectly fine in the spring.
Glass Frogs are living X-rays. Their abdominal skin is completely transparent, allowing you to watch their heart beat and their last meal digest in real-time.
The African Hairy Frog is a «Wolverine» in disguise. When threatened, it intentionally breaks its own toe bones to push them through its skin, creating sharp, defensive claws.
Bullfrogs don’t really sleep. Studies have shown that even when resting, they remain responsive to stimuli, suggesting they may go months without true shut-eye.
The Desert Rain Frog sounds like a squeaky toy. Instead of a deep croak, it emits a high-pitched «meep» to ward off predators, which usually just makes it look adorable.
Frogs swallow with their eyeballs. They use their eyes to help push food down their throats by pulling them down into the roof of their mouths.
Some frogs have «mustaches» made of thorns. The Emei mustache toad grows skin spikes during mating season to use as weapons against other males.
The Paradoxical Frog shrinks as it grows up. The tadpoles are nearly 10 inches long, but they shrink down to a mere 3 inches once they reach adulthood.
Purple Frogs spend 50 weeks a year underground. They only emerge for two weeks during the monsoon season to find a mate and lay eggs.
The Borneo Flat-headed Frog has no lungs. It breathes entirely through its skin, which allows it to absorb more oxygen from the fast-flowing, cold water it calls home.
Gastric-brooding frogs give birth through their mouths. The female swallows her fertilized eggs and shuts off her stomach acid while the babies develop inside her.
Surinam Toads carry their young in their backs. The eggs are embedded into the mother’s skin, and eventually, fully formed toadlets erupt directly from her pores.
Strawberry Poison Dart Frogs are dedicated commuters. The mother carries each individual tadpole on her back to a separate water-filled bromeliad leaf high in the canopy.
Male Darwin’s Frogs use their vocal sacs as nurseries. After the female lays eggs, the male swallows them and keeps the developing tadpoles in his throat until they hop out.
The Marsupial Frog has a built-in backpack. Females have a pouch on their backs where they keep their eggs safe until they are ready to hatch into tadpoles.
The Golden Poison Frog carries enough venom to kill 10 humans. It doesn’t produce the toxin itself but sequesters it from the specific beetles it eats in the wild.
Black Rain Frogs look like grumpy avocados. Their round, subterranean bodies and permanent scowls have made them a viral sensation for looking perpetually disappointed.
Crucifix Toads produce their own «super glue». When harassed, they secrete a sticky protein that hardens in seconds, often gluing the mouth of a predator shut.
The Wallace’s Flying Frog has «parachutes» for feet. Massive webbing between its toes allows it to glide from tree to tree to escape danger.
Frogs can’t vomit in the traditional sense. If a frog eats something toxic, it may eject its entire stomach out of its mouth to «wash» it with its paws before swallowing it back down.
Gladiator Frogs build their own private swimming pools. Males dig circular depressions in the mud near riverbanks to create protected nurseries for their eggs.
The Map Frog has skin that looks like a topographical map. This intricate pattern allows it to blend perfectly into the leaf litter and mossy bark of the Amazon.
Some frogs can change color like chameleons. Certain species, like the Pacific Tree Frog, can shift from green to brown in minutes to match their immediate surroundings.
The Turtle Frog looks more like a raw hamburger than an amphibian. It has a round, fleshy body and tiny limbs designed for digging forward into termite mounds rather than hopping.
Fanged Frogs have «bone spurs» in their lower jaws. While not true teeth, these sharp protrusions are used to battle other males and even take down large insects or small crabs.
The Budgett’s Frog is known as the «Freddy Krueger» of frogs. It is highly aggressive and will actually scream and lung at anything it perceives as a threat.
Waxy Monkey Frogs don’t dry out in the sun. They secrete a waxy lipid from their skin and use their legs to «lotion» their entire bodies to seal in moisture.
Cane Toads are notoriously undiscriminating eaters. They will eat almost anything that fits in their mouths, including insects, small mammals, and even pet food left outside.
The Tomato Frog inflates like a balloon when scared. If a predator tries to bite it, the frog also secretes a gummy white toxin that can glue the predator’s eyes and mouth shut.
Some frogs eat their own shed skin. Since skin contains valuable proteins and nutrients, many species pull their old skin off with their mouths and swallow it whole.
The South American Horned Frog is nicknamed the «Pac-Man» frog. Its mouth makes up nearly half of its body, allowing it to swallow prey almost as large as itself.
A frog’s tongue is attached to the front of its mouth. This allows the tongue to flip forward at incredible speeds, acting like a sticky whip to snag flies.
Frogs are actually «living fossils». Ancestors of modern frogs have been hopping around the Earth for over 250 million years, predating many dinosaurs.
The Titicaca Water Frog is also called the «Scrotum Frog». It has excessive, baggy folds of skin that help it absorb oxygen in the thin air of high-altitude lakes.
The Goliath Frog is the largest in the world. It can grow up to 12.5 inches long and weigh as much as a domestic cat.
Some frogs use ultrasound to talk over waterfalls. The Hole-in-the-wall Frog emits frequencies so high that humans can’t hear them, but they pierce right through the roar of rushing water.
Frogs have a «third eye» on top of their heads. Known as the parietal organ, it looks like a small dot and helps them detect light and navigate using the sun.
The Coqui frog’s call is as loud as a lawnmower. In Hawaii, where they are invasive, their nighttime choruses reach decibels high enough to cause sleep deprivation in residents.
Frogs can hear with their lungs. Some species use their lung tissue to pick up sound vibrations and pass them along to their inner ears.
The Woodhouse’s Toad has a call that sounds like a sheep’s bleat. If you were walking through a forest at night, you might genuinely think you were surrounded by tiny, invisible farm animals.
The Bird-poop Frog is a master of «disgusting» camouflage. It has a lumpy, white-and-brown body that makes it look exactly like a fresh bird dropping to avoid being eaten.
Vietnamese Mossy Frogs are essentially invisible. Their skin is covered in green and black bumps that perfectly mimic the texture of damp forest moss.
The Pebbles Toad turns into a ball to escape. Instead of hopping away from predators on cliffs, it tucks its limbs in and bounces down the rocks like a piece of rubber.
Malayan Leaf Frogs have literal «horns» above their eyes. These skin flaps mimic the tips of dead leaves, helping them disappear into the forest floor.
The Shovel-headed Tree Frog uses its head as a door. It retreats into holes in trees and uses its flat, bony skull to plug the entrance, keeping predators out.
Phyllomedusa frogs produce «Kambo» secretions. Some indigenous tribes use this toxic skin mucus in traditional rituals to induce «cleansing» through intense physical reactions.
The Mink Frog smells like a rotten onion. When handled or stressed, it releases a pungent odor that mimics the scent of decaying vegetables to ward off handlers.
Frogs are the source of a powerful new painkiller. Scientists discovered a compound in the skin of the Epipedobates tricolor that is 200 times more potent than morphine.
Bicolor Leaf Frogs use «sunscreen». They produce a secretion that reflects UV rays, allowing them to bask in the tropical sun without damaging their sensitive skin.
The Fire-bellied Toad uses its belly as a warning sign. When threatened, it arches its back to show off its bright orange underside, signaling to predators that it is toxic.
The Paedophryne amauensis is the smallest vertebrate in the world. This tiny frog from Papua New Guinea is only about 7.7 millimeters long, fitting easily on a fingernail.
Some frogs can survive in the desert for years. The Water-holding Frog creates a waterproof cocoon of shed skin and stays dormant underground until it rains.
